text: Thanks <@UFBNA9K9A> any advice on the best middleware software to use to create something like this?

The logic seems to be using a fetch api to pull information from some sort of middleware that would then update the Deal stage in HubSpot. So when building the information for the "update a deal" endpoint this would contain in its body every deal stage and deal pipeline in order for it to be associated correctly?

Zapier is probably the most common middleware with HubSpot but there are others out there like Tibco Scribe and Bedrock though I’m not sure if either of them have a connection to VTiger.  I know Scribe has a generic HTTP connector so you could use that if Zapier doesnt’ have what you need
You shouldn’t need every deal stage, just the one you want to change it to
Thanks I though the logic would be it would have to map to if there was 5 deals stages in HS then there should be 5 stages in vtiger to map accordingly...?
Well, yes you do have to have maintain the mapping of stages, that’s what the middleware would do
Thanks <@UFBNA9K9A> should this entire setup take more than a day to create in your opinion?
Hi guys, pardon my ignorance with this, think I'm missing something here...where do I install this? On the CMS where I need to pull the blogs from?
you run it locally <@U6W3H6YN8> may be able to explain better. The hair be with you. :will:

---- UPDATE: Disregard! My acct mgr got this set up, I'm in good shape shape :sunglasses: ---- I'm re-doing a HubSpot site (pro level) and would like to be able to develop on a subdomain in a separate environment. My acct mgr said I could do this with a dev account but it looks like that's for developing applications. Is there a way to do what I want without spinning up a new pro account? Thanks.
Hey Cory! Have you checked out Content Stating yet? That might be a better tool for your use-case
I haven't but I will look into it, thanks!
was just about to say your CAM should be able to do this but they may be frerring to the sandbox account from the developer kit: <https://designers.HubSpot.com/discoverykit/sandbox>

Hey <@U9MAWTESW>, this is something you'd run locally. You need the Java SDK (jdk?) installed in order to run it. The output of the program is a .xml file that is friendly to HubSpot's blog import tool.
Currently, the API that was used for converting the vast array of possible publish date formats into the required format for HubSpot's blog importer is down...not sure if/when we can expect a fix there.
If that's not an issue for you, it otherwise works quite well in most cases.
